```{r}

fruits <- list("apple", "banana", "apple")

for (i in 1:length(fruits)) {
  fruits[[i]] <- paste0(fruits[[i]], "_nuf")
}

print(fruits)
```

```{r}

first4 <- list(c("item1", "item2"), c("item3", "item4"), c("item5", "item6"))

for (i in 1:length(first4)) {
  first4[[i]][1] <- paste(first4[[i]][1], "Add", sep="")
}

# Print the modified list
print(first4)
```

```{r}
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Assuming you have a data frame 'df' with columns 'A' and 'Category'
# Generate example data (you would use your own data)
set.seed(123) # for reproducibility
df <- data.frame(
  A = rnorm(400),
  Category = factor(rep(0:3, each = 100))
)

# Create the violin plot with boxplot overlay
ggplot(df, aes(x = Category, y = A)) +
  geom_violin(trim = FALSE, fill = "lightgray") +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.1, outlier.shape = NA, fill = "white") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Category", x = "A")

# Display the plot
ggsave("violin_boxplot.png", width = 8, height = 6)

```
```{r}
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Assuming you have a data frame 'df' with columns 'A' and 'Category'
# Generate example data (you would use your own data)
set.seed(123) # for reproducibility
df <- data.frame(
  A = rnorm(400),
  Category = factor(rep(0:3, each = 100))
)

# Create the violin plot with boxplot and strip plot overlay
ggplot(df, aes(x = Category, y = A)) +
  # geom_violin(trim = FALSE, fill = "lightgray") +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, size = 1, alpha = 0.5, aes(color = Category)) +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.1, outlier.shape = NA, fill = "white", alpha = 0, aes(color = Category)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Category", x = "A")

# Display the plot           
# ggsave("violin_box_strip_plot.png", width = 8, height = 6)

```
